field_edited_text.value:
1. Review and Analysis of Existing Studies
Existing reports were examined to determine
the present function of each area, the size and
scope of its retail sector, characteristics of its
trade area population, and prospective
population and income levels. In addition, each
area was evaluated in terms of special problems
and assets.

General data regarding the city and the region
were examined as a framework for evaluating
the market potential of the three areas. Any
renewal activities, transportation proposals or
similar programs were evaluated to determine
their possible socio-economic effect on each
area.

2. Surveys

A mail survey was conducted among merchants
in the three study areas to gather information
relating to current sales trends, improvements
carried out or planned, and opinions regarding
ways of improving business.

Personal interviews were also carried out among
merchants in the three areas to get a firsthand
impression of their views on the business
outlook, the effects of planned or proposed
public activities such as mass transit and urban
renewal, and' feasible recommendations for
improving their area. It was also possible to
obtain from this survey some idea of the degree
of participation that could be expected in any
improvement program.

Other factors considered in the survey were
traffic and parking conditions, quality and type
of merchandise, driving time to competing
centers and general appearance of the study
area.

Surveys were also conducted of residents of the
trade areas of the three shopping centers to
determine shopping habits and preferences,
income and age groups, and attitudes toward
the facilities or lack of them in the three areas.

The market studies showed that the three
centers are highly dependent on the
surrounding residential areas for their economic
survival because most of their customers are
those who can walk there to shop.

But family income is low, unemployment rates
are high and there is steady decline in the

population of the three surrounding areas. All
of these factors contribute to a declining
market for the goods and services offered by
business in the three centers.

The three areas differ in some of their
socio-economic characteristics.

The Pennsylvania Avenue area, for example, is
in a predominantly Black neighborhood and for
many years was the main shopping area for
most Black people in Baltimore. Local
merchants indicated that many of their
customers continued to shop in the
Pennsylvania Avenue area after moving out of
the neighborhood.

The core of the shopping area has no vacancies
and higher than average sales volume. The
public market plays an important role in the
neighborhood and its sales figures amount to
$93 per square foot, compared to $78 for other
public markets.

Despite this, Pennsylvania Avenue merchants
are losing their customers. Between 1950 and
1960, the trade area population decreased by
20 percent. Urban renewal clearance has since
increased the downward trend. In addition,
changes in social attitudes; €conomic gains and
other factors have enabled many Black people
to move to other parts of the city. Further
clearance programs are expected to result in a
further 23 percent decline in population by
0.

The loss of customers and the continued
prospect of further decreases have caused
merchants--the majority of whom rent
premises--to hesitate in making further financial
commitments in the area.

The Light Street Area has no vacant stores in its
retail core and higher than average sales
volumes. There are vacant stores on the fringes
of the area and some marginal stores along
Charles Street. Although the public market
occupies a prime location, it is not used to its
fullest extent--27 percent of the stalls were

not rented at the time of this study.

The area’s population of 36,300 is primarily
blue-collar workers and about one-third is
Black. This results in merchants being faced
with varying and sometimes conflictin

demands for goods and services. The population



decreased by 23 percent between 1950 aﬁd
1960.

Problems in the Light Street area are not as
evident as in the Pennsylvania Avenue area, but
merchants are growing uncertain about the
future and are less inclined to invest in
improvements. Although the proposed Inner
Harbor project will add more than 1,000
dwelling units to the adjacent area, the
merchants feel that because they will have
higher incomes and because of the project’s
proximity to the CBD, the new residents will
shop elsewhere.

In contrast, Monument Street had a relatively
stable population between 1950 and 1960; the
median income was only slightly below the city
average and unemployment was relatively
moderate. The number of Black residents is
gradually increasing and merchants indicated
that their clientele is about evenly divided
between white and Black.

Although vacancy rates are low in the core area,
there are higher than average vacancies in the
fringe areas of the shopping center. The public
market occupies a prime location but 12
percent of its space is not rented and sales
volumes are low.

Expansion of Johns Hopkins Hospital facilities
is expected to add several thousand employees
and some permanent residents to the area.
Projections indicate an increasing population
but the shifting ethnic distribution may cause
problems for merchants.
